citations.narrative:
The temporary metal enclosure for the Black-headed Night monkey or Owl Monkey, has a few areas of rust present on
some of the bottom bars. The monkey could come in contact with these rusted areas. Rust cannot be readily cleaned and
sanitized. The rusted areas should be repaired or the owl monkey should be placed in another enclosure.
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that it enables all surfaces in contact with nonhuman primates
to be readily cleaned and sanitized in accordance with Sec. 3.84(b)(3) of this subpart, or replaced when worn or soiled.

Three of the 4 cases of Zupreem Marmoset diet in the feed building, were dated Best By 9/21. The third case was dated
Best By 3/23. One open case, in the kitchen of the main building, had 8 cans remaining out of 12. The Best By date on
this case and on the cans were 3/23. Expired foods have lost their nutritive value and use of it as food is not beneficial to
the health of the common marmosets present. The common marmosets must be provided with wholesome and palatable
food that is in date for their health and well-being.
The food must be clean, wholesome, and palatable to the animals. It must be of sufficient quantity and have sufficient
nutritive value to maintain a healthful condition and weight range of the animal and to meet its normal daily nutritional
requirements.

The wallaby has a large Rubbermaid tub in the outdoor portion of its enclosure. The wallaby could rest inside of this tub if
it so desired. The top edge has four areas that are damaged and exposing jagged, hard rubber that could cause harm or
injury to the wallaby while entering or exiting this tub. This damaged tub should be replaced to protect the wallaby from
injury.
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals.

Housekeeping.
The following areas are in need of repair and/or replacement:
* The dividing wall, that keeps the public away from the fennec fox enclosure, has broken lattice present and it is
completely leaning. This wall is not secured and is structurally unsound.
* The top rail of the barrier fence across from the common marmosets has deteriorated on one end. This deterioration has
left the end with a 2.5 inch chunk of wood missing thus leaving jagged edges present.
These damaged areas leave the facility in disrepair and they should be repaired to maintain structural strength and
integrity.
Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to
facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart.

Pest control.
The black vultures were again observed walking next to the Asiatic Bear as well as on the grounds of the primary
enclosure. These birds present a health hazard with their droppings in and around the bear enclosure. According to staff,
methods to remove the birds have been attempted but have not been very effective. A more suitable method to remove
these birds and prevent their return should be established.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be
established and maintained.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 7, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.80(a)(2)(ix)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
The temporary metal enclosure for the Black-headed Night monkey or Owl Monkey, has a few areas of rust present on 
some of the bottom bars. The monkey could come in contact with these rusted areas. Rust cannot be readily cleaned and 
sanitized. The rusted areas should be repaired or the owl monkey should be placed in another enclosure. 
 
Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that it enables all surfaces in contact with nonhuman primates 
to be readily cleaned and sanitized in accordance with Sec. 3.84(b)(3) of this subpart, or replaced when worn or soiled. 
3.82(a) 
   
Feeding. 
Three of the 4 cases of Zupreem Marmoset diet in the feed building, were dated Best By 9/21. The third case was dated 
Best By 3/23. One open case, in the kitchen of the main building, had 8 cans remaining out of 12. The Best By date on 
this case and on the cans were 3/23. Expired foods have lost their nutritive value and use of it as food is not beneficial to 
the health of the common marmosets present. The common marmosets must be provided with wholesome and palatable 
food that is in date for their health and well-being. 
 
The food must be clean, wholesome, and palatable to the animals. It must be of sufficient quantity and have sufficient 
nutritive value to maintain a healthful condition and weight range of the animal and to meet its normal daily nutritional 
requirements. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The wallaby has a large Rubbermaid tub in the outdoor portion of its enclosure. The wallaby could rest inside of this tub if 
it so desired. The top edge has four areas that are damaged and exposing jagged, hard rubber that could cause harm or 
injury to the wallaby while entering or exiting this tub. This damaged tub should be replaced to protect the wallaby from 
injury. 
 
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals.

3.131(c)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
Housekeeping.  
The following areas are in need of repair and/or replacement: 
 
* The dividing wall, that keeps the public away from the fennec fox enclosure, has broken lattice present and it is 
completely leaning. This wall is not secured and is structurally unsound. 
 
* The top rail of the barrier fence across from the common marmosets has deteriorated on one end. This deterioration has 
left the end with a 2.5 inch chunk of wood missing thus leaving jagged edges present. 
 
These damaged areas leave the facility in disrepair and they should be repaired to maintain structural strength and 
integrity.  
 
Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to 
facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. 
3.131(d)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
Pest control. 
 
The black vultures were again observed walking next to the Asiatic Bear as well as on the grounds of the primary 
enclosure. These birds present a health hazard with their droppings in and around the bear enclosure. According to staff, 
methods to remove the birds have been attempted but have not been very effective. A more suitable method to remove 
these birds and prevent their return should be established. 
 
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be 
established and maintained. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 7, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
